title: Shoyumame
text: is a <a href="regional%20cuisine">regional cuisine</a> of the <a href="Kagawa%20prefecture">Kagawa prefecture</a> of Japan. Shoyumame consists of <a href="Parched%20grain">parched</a> <a href="Vicia%20faba">broad beans</a> that have been left overnight in a marinade consisting primarily of soy sauce and sugar, with <a href="mirin">mirin</a> and <a href="sake">sake</a> usually included in the marinade as well. It is commonly served alongside lunch or dinner, or as an <a href="Sakana">accompaniment to alcohol</a>. Although similar in appearance, "shoyumame" should not be confused with "<a href="shoyunomi">shoyunomi</a>"—a regional dish of Nagano, Niigata, Yamagata and Kagoshima prefectures—which consists of steamed black beans that have been fermented in soy sauce with <a href="rice%20malt">rice malt</a>.
